abstract.text: A container for grouping related menu elements in an app menu or contextual menu.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: objects and use them to construct the menus and submenus your app displays. You provide menus for your app when it runs on macOS, and key command elements in those menus also appear in the discoverability HUD on iPad when someone presses the Command key. You also use menus to display contextual actions in response to specific interactions with one of your views. Every menu has a title, an optional image, and an optional set of child elements. When someone selects an element from the menu, the system executes the code you provide. The code sample below illustrates adding a menu group that contains two menu elements — New and Open — to the File menu.

code: // Ensure that the builder is modifying the menu bar system.
// Use the .displayInline option to avoid displaying the menu as a submenu,
// and to separate it from the other menu elements using a line separator.
let newMenu = UIMenu(title: "", options: .displayInline, children: [newDocument, openDocument])
// Insert the menu item at the top of the File menu.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
A container for grouping related menu elements in an app menu or contextual menu.
Constants that determine the size of an element in a menu.
Constants you use to identify an app’s standard menus.
Options you use to configure a menu’s appearance.
The contents of the menu.
An object that configures how UIKit displays the menu.
The unique identifier for the current menu.
Creates a menu from data in an unarchiver.
Creates a new menu with the specified values.
Creates a new menu with the specified title, subtitle, image, identifier, menu options, and child elements.
Creates a new menu with the specified title, subtitle, image, identifier, menu options, element size, and child elements.
Creates a new menu with the specified child elements.
Creates a menu with the specified title and child menu elements.
Creates a new menu with the specified values.
The configuration options for the current menu.
The size of the menu’s child elements.
Creates a new menu with the same configuration as the current menu, but with a new set of child elements.
The elements in the menu and its sub-menus that are in the on state.
An interface for adding and removing menus from a menu system.
An object that contains information for configuring a menu’s display.
An object representing a menu, action, or command.
An object representing a main or contextual menu system.
Provide quick access to useful actions by adding menus and keyboard shortcuts to your Mac app built with Mac Catalyst.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Adding menus and shortcuts to the menu bar and user interface

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
